item.title: A first taste of the common workflow language, part 2.
item.description: First, we start with the header information: The first two lines are self-explanatory. You have to specify the version of the spec, and that this document refers to a Workflow. Because steps 1 and 2 are essentially the same, I’ll present both below, but only go over the first step. The first two steps also include the following…

item.title: A first taste of the common workflow language, part 1.
item.description: If you go to the CWL webpage you are greeted, right at the top, by these two sentences: The Common Workflow Language (CWL) is a specification for describing analysis workflows and tools in a way that makes them portable and scalable across a variety of software and hardware environments, from workstations to cluster, cloud, and high performance computing (HPC)…
